poem:
**Christine Mason**

On linoleum lanes of the 60s,  
Christine shapes a world steady,  
unseen hands in flour and thread,  
adding and subtracting daily worth.  
Her ledger, a home—each corner  
stitched with care, each echo  
a whisper of dinner plates,  
a hearth above nettling blueprints.  
Framework tucked under wrinkle  
and apron, her infinite jest.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Christine Mason obituary My mother, Christine Mason, who has died aged 86, was a typical housewife of the 1960s and 70s, devoting much of her adult life to managing the household budget, looking after her children and doing the rounds of cooking and washing. She had worked in a bank before her marriage, after which she transferred to full-time work around the house. As a family we all appreciated the bedrock that she provided, built". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
